content.content: MIP55c3-SP14: Defense Fund  Preamble MIP55c3-SP#: 14 Author(s): @layerzero Contributors: Tags: spf Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-12-07 Date Ratified: 2023-01-23 Amount Requested: 5M DAI Recipient Address: TBD Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp14-self-insurance-fund/19076 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmUbqKMy   Sentence Summary This SPF requests 5M DAI for establishing a Defense Fund which will have the purpose of reimbursing legal defense expenses incurred by active participants of MakerDAO in case they are the target of legal or regulatory action.  Paragraph Summary The Defense Fund will be used as a contingency budget to reimburse legal defense expenses in case of legal or regulatory action against specific participants of MakerDAO. Initially, coverage will be provided to the following group of persons, which will be the initial set of beneficiaries:  Recognized Delegates Core Unit Facilitators Core Unit permanent contributors Active MKR holders (i.e., MKR voting token holders that actively participate in governance)  The legal action against the beneficiary must be directly related to its activities at MakerDAO.  Motivation Self-insurance is a well-known risk management technique that consists in setting funds aside for covering a possible future cost. Technically, it is a tool for retaining and managing risks professionally. Typically self-insurance is used when risk can not be transferred through traditional insurance. Self-insurance instruments can be used as an alternative or a complement to insurance. DAOs are novel organizational structures and, as such, may expose their participants to novel legal risks. MakerDAO is not a legal subject, hence is unable to limit liability risks for its participants. Self-insurances are customizable instruments that can be tailor-made to manage novel or complex risks. Therefore, they are suitable risk management instruments for DAOs.  Special Purpose Fund Name Defense Fund  Special Purpose Fund Scope & Work Credentials This SPF will be used as a contingency budget with the purpose of covering legal defense costs in case a MakerDAO stakeholder is a target of legal action. All claims and payouts will be managed according to a process contained in the Claim Procedure Manual. This Procedure Manual is under development by the companies Gallagher and Artex. These companies are world leaders in insurance and risk management and have successfully delivered a feasibility study. This feasibility study analyzes the average legal defense costs in jurisdictions where MakerDAO participants have most exposure, describes possible legal and operational setups for the fund, determines its minimum capital requirements, and recommends coverage amounts and limits. Additionally, the feasibility study describes the claim process, which will be as follows:  A beneficiary is the target of a legal or regulatory action and requires legal representation. The beneficiary must first assume its legal expenses and then, if eligible, submit a claim to the fund for reimbursing legal costs. Claims must be accompanied by supporting documentation. Claims are first submitted to an external technical committee. This committee will be composed of insurance and risk management experts. They will verify the eligibility of the claimant, assess the claim, and evaluate supportive documentation. Based on this information, they will issue a recommendation to approve or reject a payout. The committee will have a term of 8 (eight) working days to make a decision. This recommendation will be submitted to the SPF multisig signers. According to the rules contained in MIP55c2, the funds in escrow must be in a multisig with signatory requirements of a minimum of two Comptrollers. Comptrollers will review the recommendation of the technical committee and decide whether they approve it or they reject it. If approved, funds will be released to the final recipient’s designated address, which is a whitelisted address controlled by the beneficiary. If they reject it, they must provide an explanation on their reasons. From the moment that the external committee recommendations reach the Comptrollers, they have a term of 8 (eight) working days to execute the payout or provide an explanation on why they reject it. During this term, they can request additional information or opinions from the external committee.  The Claim Procedure Manual will define all necessary operational aspects, including:  User Guide Registration process Elaboration of terms of use Definition of beneficiaries Policy description, coverage amounts and exclusions Claim process, timing, and decision-making rules Requisites for submitting a claim, required supporting documentation and forms Process for updating the Claim Procedure Manual (i.e., variation of coverage amounts or inclusion of new beneficiaries to include new emerging roles in the Endgame Plan).   Funding Breakdown  Funding will be done in a lump sum upon governance approval of the SPF. Funds in this SPF are destined as a contingency budget for covering legal defense and legal representation expenses. Funds in this SPF will not cover operational costs of the project. Payout decisions and claim management will follow the ruleset contained in the Claim Procedure Manual. The Maker Protocol (MCD_PAUSE_PROXY, 0xBE8E3e3618f7474F8cB1d074A26afFef007E98FB) will be listed as a beneficiary on the multisig wallet. This allows the protocol to withdraw funds from the multisig wallet, ensuring control over these funds.   Special Purpose Fund Details Official Contact : @layerzero Contact Email/Handle: [email protected] Date Added: (yyyy-mm-dd) Total Amount: In Dai. 5M DAI Wallet Address: Public wallet address of Multi-Sig.  TBD Comptroller signers: @tadeo (https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp14-self-insurance-fund/19076/54), @prose11 (https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp14-self-insurance-fund/19076/56)

content.content: Looking good. This fund is for actors in their official capacity right? In other words, this doesn’t cover folks in their personal capacity?

Thank you for your question. MakerDAO is not a company nor is incorporated as a legal entity. Therefore, participants in the DAO (workforce and governors) have, in theory, a higher risk exposure than employees in a traditional centralized organization. You are totally right, self-insurance is quite different from insurance;  the former is about risk retention and the latter about risk transfer.

content.content: No, it is not related to this case or any other in particular. Prior or pending claims are excluded from coverage.
The idea is to have a contingency budget for legal defense that is segregated from the operational budget, immediately available when needed.
Exactly. The legal action must be directly related to the activity / role of the beneficiary at MakerDAO.

Exciting to see MakerDAO taking these steps forward. DAO contributors face quite unknown legal exposures when compared to employees of legal corporations and if the wider DAO space is to flourish we need to offer backstops of some kind. Relative to entirely offloading this risk to an insurance company (DeFi or Traditional) I like the approach of creating a self-insurance fund as step one as it is a concrete step that demonstrates MakerDAO’s commitment to supporting their contributors and also socialising that risk with the wider group of MKR holders. A key next step here would be to get the details on the policy wording to understand exactly what is intended to be covered as with these types of coverage certain exclusions can materially change the value to the holders. I understand this is a work in progress so am just noting this point as I’m personally very keen to see the details. Switching hats to my view as the Founder of Nexus Mutual, there is also an opportunity to share this risk with Nexus. This could be done is various ways, but likely as an excess layer on-top of the initial fund. For example:  The insurance fund takes 100% of losses up to $xm Nexus Mutual takes 80% of losses above $xm up to $ym, witht he remaining 20% being taken by the insurance fund to maintain incentive alignment.  The most obvious structure if for Nexus Mutual to simply “follow claims” and therefore just pay when the financial triggers are hit based on the Claim Procedure Manual. We are more than happy to collaborate on these points as required and would be happy to come back with a proposal after seeing the detailed cover wording.

Say there is some event where a government agency investigates and/or charges a DAO contributor for participating in the DAO. The legal costs incurred in this defense are very likely covered by the terms this self-insurance fund is providing. Say the defense costs then exceed the limits agreed with Nexus, then this would result in a valid claim. The claim would be handled in the usual way via Nexus Mutual’s claims assessment. Nexus has paid almost $10m in claims since it’s launch in May 2019 and you can read more about how claims are handled in our docs etc. I believe this is one of your points, ie can Nexus be relied on to pay valid claims. I can provide more info here, but this is a separate point to the underlying cause of the claim which can come from anywhere, on-chain or off-chain. Nexus claims assessors can use any information they need to (on-chain or off-chain) to decide in the validity of claims in line with the cover wording. Humans vote and reflect those views on chain.

content.content: This is Guangmian, Integrations and Partnerships lead from Kleros. This self-insurance proposal is a great step forward for decentralized projects like Maker and showcases how novel arrangements can be deployed by DAOs to approximate the functions of traditional organizations and services. I just want to mention that it is important that the contributors that require assistance from the SIF are able to do so in a swift, permissionless and trustless way. Decentralizing this process is tricky as, DeFi insurance setups are vulnerable to the reverse agency problem esp if the DAO members are the ones voting to use their own funds to protect select members of the DAO. To avoid this problem, the ideal solution for such situations is to delegate the claim decision to a fully decentralized process, i.e. to a subjective oracle to interpret the rules and procedures written by the DAO at the time of setup of the SIF. Kleros has been the leading arbitration and subjective oracle solution provider in this space, and has helped Unslashed Finance (the leading provider of UST depeg insurance during the Terra Luna downfall) to secure more than $20 million in claims in just the past 12 months. We will be following this MIP closely and will be on standby to assist if Maker would like to have a chat on how to fully decentralize the SIF payout process in a trustless, secure and credibly neutral manner.

content.content: LinkMarine:  The good news for those keeping up with DAO legal developments, particularly in the US, is that DAOs are successfully fending off every attempt at regulation and litigation.   This is a TERRIBLE take, incorrect and the wrong conclusion to draw. Community is cautioned against taking any comfort from armchair pontifications based on clickbait headlines. Please understand the details here and read the Order for yourselves: https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.cand.400807/gov.uscourts.cand.400807.59.0.pdf Not one single thing has changed with respect to the DAO being lawfully served as initially approved. The judge has now merely stated that known token holders (the Founders) should ALSO be personally served. "As will be detailed in that order, it seems clear in this case that Ooki DAO has actual notice of the litigation. But to provide the best practicable notice, the CFTC should serve at least one identifiable Token Holder if that is possible. I will delay entering that order until the CFTC has made that attempt, as discussed in the next paragraph. The CFTC is now ORDERED to serve Bean and Kistner, in their roles as Ooki DAO Token Holders, with the complaint and all relevant documents in this case at the earliest time practicable. If the CFTC is unable to do so, it is ordered to show cause why service is impossible. The CFTC must file confirmation of service or its response to show cause no later than January 11, 2023." Now, the plot twist is that the Founders attorney is saying they are no longer part of the DAO, so what will CFTC do about that? In no way does that imply the DAO’s service was ineffective. Again, as quoted above from the order linked the Judge is tell us: As will be detailed in that order, it seems clear in this case that Ooki DAO has actual notice of the litigation. We must wait and see.

content.content: LinkMarine:  Good question. The proposal does suggest that MakerDAO is itself legally transparent, and the proposal would skip over MakerDAO for the benefit of delegates, contributors, etc.   The main purpose of this instrument is to protect persons involved in MakerDAO. MakerDAO is not a company nor is incorporated as a legal entity. The main purpose of legal entities is to limit liability risks, so we need first to de risk involvement of individual stakeholders. As we all know, DAOs are novel organizational structures that are not legally recognized nor have legal personality (There are some exceptions, like the Wyoming DAO law, which has its own set of problems, but that would be topic for another forum post). More generally, I see DAOs more as a set of rules encoded by smart contracts and enforced on a blockchain.     fumoffuXx:  Even though Recognised delegates are identifiable. it will be a jurisdiction nightmare to launch a litigation suite to off US shore individuals.   The fund will provide worldwide coverage. This means, it doesn’t matter where  the beneficiary is located or in which jurisdiction the legal action takes place. The main condition is that the suit is directly related to the activity of that person at Maker.     fumoffuXx:  I still think the name needs to change to a “Litigation Provision”. As MAKER is setting aside a pool of funds for litigation reimbursements.   I think Self Insurance describes well this instrument, but happy to reconsider naming options! If we do it, I would prefer more general terms like Legal Defense or Legal Protection Fund.     fig:  Is it possible by creating and announcing a fund of this size it invites more legal proceedings and attacks? Seems like it can get resource intensive, quick.   More than a legal bounty, the SIF is a contingency fund with a very specific purpose: reimburse legal defense costs. The payouts are not discretionary; they will be subject to detailed policy contained in the Claim Procedure Manual and the claims will be assessed by a professional, technical team. Proper legal defense can be very onerous and out of reach to individual contributors. We want to assure that persons involved in the DAO have the best possible defense, and a contingency fund is the first step in this direction. This should deter future lawsuits.

content.content: Part 2. “How atomica.org can help?” The Atomica.org team is developing insurance as a service framework. It looks like Uniswap V3 for insurance. Any protocol or DAO may use Atomica framework for the insurance and risk markets deployment. Atomica.org framework may significantly reduce the insurance and risk market development time and OPEX cost. We would be happy to assist you in the Maker DAO Legal Expenses Insurance (LEI) risk market creation and configuration. Atomica.org framework benefits:   Neutrality. We are not trying to be an insurance company. We position ourselves as the insurance and risk market framework which connects the dots between the demand side (policy buyers) and supply side (reinsurance providers). Both parties can benefit from using the framework.  No conflict of interests. By design Atomica.org has segregated claim and payout approver roles. The MakerDAO committee may use multisig, voting tools or external tools like Kleros, Uma to control the claims and payouts process.  Whitelists. To avoid insider games, only MakerDAO and DAO members 0x addresses can be whitelisted. Only MakerDAO and DAO members will be able to buy the Maker DAO LPI or LEI insurance. Thanks to perpetual NFT policies MakerDAO can buy the LEI insurance centrally and send policies to DAO members. DAO members can manage policies on their own. It works like a mobile data plan, MakerDAO members can increase or decrease policy coverage capacity, may top-up or withdraw policy balance. SIF fund or part of the fund may be connected to the MakerDAO risk market as the external reinsurance pool. The external reinsurance pool funds are controlled by MakerDAO multisig and not affected by the smart contract hacking risk. MakerDAO SIF fund can be used as a junior tranche or first loss pool.  3rd party underwriters incentivization. If MakerDAO needs more than $5M LEI coverage capacity, the 3rd party reinsurance pools can be connected to MakerDAO LEI risk market. To accelerate and bootstrap the MakerDAO risk market, underwriters can be incentivized by the MKR or other ERC20 tokens.  The next steps to proceed forward: We already prepared the closed live demo Maker DAI LEI insurance.  Access can be allowed for google accounts provided by the MakerDAO. It would be nice if you can provide the 0x address for the Claim Processor and Payout Comptroller’s. Next we can prepare the Maker DAI LEI insurance live demo - use cases documentation.  Risk market technical specification preparation:  Policy wording Whitelisted policy buyers 0x addresses Risk tower, reinsurance pools structure Premium token - DAI (The insurance premiums will be paid in DAI) 3rd party underwriters reinsurance pool token - USDC, Eth, etc? Withdraw delay for underwriters and LPs  Any feedback is welcome and appreciated. Best regards, Atomica.org integration team

content.content: Thoughts from a US civil litigation attorney. – this is a good idea if limited to the retention and payment of attorney’s fees and litigation costs and not to pay a claim.  For a potential claimant to know that any of the members have attorneys at their disposal to defeat a claim, that will dissuade litigation.  For a potential claimant to know that there is a bucket of DAI for payment of claims, that will encourage litigation. – it does not and should not be 5 MM.   1 MM DAI, put into Yearn or elsewhere that it can be easily obtained, is sufficient, with some caveat that with a DAO vote additional DAI can be allocated to particular defense. – the terms must be that it is a “claims made” contract, meaning that its coverage is not based upon the date of the alleged negligent act like your homeowner’s policy, but when a demand by a claimant is made.  Someone asked if this is to cover March 2020 claims and the response was no - good.  But I’m concerned this is being proposed because someone already knows about a claim - that must be excluded without full disclosure to the DAO members.  Coverage must be denied if a claim has been made before this is implemented without full disclosure that this may be used for an already-made claim, however informally made.  Once implemented, it should require for coverage that within X days that a member gets a claim that the member caused the claimant harm, however informal and even without a demand for compensation, it should be reported to someone so it can be assessed.

content.content: I hereby confirm my participation as a comptroller.

Thank you for your comments. Self-insurance is a risk management instrument that is fundamentally different from insurance. While the latter is about risk transfer to a third party (i.e. insurance company) the former is about risk retention. Self-insurance is commonly used when risk can’t be transferred through traditional insurance, which is a typical situation in crypto. Self-insurance can also be used in combination with traditional insurance. Sometimes insurers will require that the customer takes a first loss, which could be in the form of a deductible or a self-insurance instrument, to provide coverage. This SPF covers only the self-insurance component. This component can work without a legal entity. We need a claims procedure with a description of policy, exclusions, process, etc.  We also need a technical committee to process the claims, work that can be done by Gallagher /  Artex or another insurance expert. This framework is under development by Gallagher and we expect the final version by the end of January. With the Self-insurance instrument in place, we can go to the insurance markets to seek extended coverage in excess of 5MM, or include additional stakeholders or risks. For this part, we will most probably need a legal entity that signs the insurance contracts. This entity would act as a policyholder, and the beneficiaries would be MakerDAO stakeholders. Again, this is not part of this SPF but can be an interesting next development as part of a comprehensive risk management strategy. I am also open to changing the name of the proposal, as I see that is causing some confusion. Maybe Protection or Defense Fund could be good naming alternatives.

I’m aware this has already passed, but I want to highlight two serious issues with this setup. The first is pretty simple. This results in $5M being custodied by a 2/3 multi-sig. This feels extremely risky to me, regardless of the character of those involved. I don’t believe this level of multi-sig / personal security risk is present anywhere else in the DAO. I strongly suspect that at least 2 of the signers have been present in the same physical location at one or more previous MakerDAO meetups. I’m aware that MIP55 is not the most well-written MIP, but I strongly suggest that those involved with this SPF find a compliant way to add additional signers to the multi-sig while maintaining the 2/3rd majority of signers required to access funds prior to funds being distributed. Second, and slightly more complicated, I don’t believe it makes sense to hold these funds in Dai in the manner that has been proposed. Consider the following scenarios:  An individual covered by the fund is sued at a time when the Maker Protocol is not insolvent and surplus buffer funds are available. In this situation, there is no need for the funds to be held in DAI outside of governance’s control. An individual covered by the fund is used at a time when the Maker Protocol is insolvent and surplus buffer funds are not available. In this situation, Dai is likely not worth $1, and the fund may not be able to cover legal defences.  If the intention is to reliably provide legal defence funds in both of these scenarios, I would suggest swapping the Dai to an alternative centralized stable (or a basket of such). If the intention is only to support scenario #1, the funds should be held in the surplus buffer or the pause-proxy contract where they are not vulnerable to risks related to multi-sigs.  Pings to ensure people see this, as it is easy to lose things on the forum. @Recognized-Delegates @tadeo @prose11 @layerzero

Dear community members: After discussing matters with the rest of the team, I want to give an update on the next steps for the defense fund.   We want to thank again all @Recognized-Delegates  that supported our proposal. In spite of the majority vote, we already decided to put the proposal on hold, at least until we defined and agreed on key implementation details (e.g. trust architecture of multisigs holding funds used to absorb legal risks). We posted this message shortly before the planned executive vote:    982×388 38.6 KB    Upon further consideration, we think that the best way forward is to work first on two related fronts, before we return to the funding proposal itself:   a) The Claim Procedure Manual, describing all operational requirements and procedures, which is under development and will be shared shortly.   b) Physical Resiliency Scope Framework, which will describe general policies and requirements for managing and mitigating legal risk in the context of the Endgame Plan.     The Defense Fund is designed to be a first-loss, self-insured fund, that will serve as the building block of a long term legal risk management strategy we envision for MakerDAO. It is therefore critical to carefully analyze and discuss it in the context of the Resiliency Scope Framework, to consider necessary adjustments and make it endgame-compatible.   We look forward to the upcoming discussions!
